definitions: having deteriorated through age, contamination, or mishandling and no longer fit for use
given excessive attention and privileges resulting in demanding or selfish behavior
examples: The spoiled milk had a terrible sour smell
We threw away the spoiled food after the power outage
Their spoiled daughter expected expensive gifts every week
The spoiled child threw tantrums when denied anything

definitions: having deteriorated through age, contamination, or mishandling and no longer usable
given too much attention and indulgence resulting in selfish or difficult behavior
examples: The spoilt vegetables were thrown into the compost
She noticed the spoilt fish before cooking it
His spoilt nephew demanded the latest gaming console
The spoilt prince never learned to share with others

meanings: having a specified manner of speaking
definitions: communicated or expressed through speech rather than writing or other means
characterized by a particular way or quality of verbal expression
examples: The spoken agreement wasn't legally binding without documentation
Her spoken English was better than her written skills
The soft-spoken librarian helped students find their books
A well-spoken candidate impressed the interview panel

definitions: having a soft, elastic, porous texture that compresses easily under pressure
having qualities similar to a sponge in appearance, texture, or absorption
examples: The spongy moss felt soft beneath their feet
The cake had a perfect spongy texture
The spongy material absorbed all the spilled liquid
His spongy bones were a sign of osteoporosis

definitions: happening or arising without apparent external cause or deliberate planning
performed or occurring as a result of sudden inner impulse without premeditation
examples: The spontaneous applause surprised the nervous performer
A spontaneous fire broke out in the storage room
Her spontaneous decision to travel changed her life
They enjoyed a spontaneous picnic in the park

definitions: causing fear or unease through supernatural or mysterious qualities
having an atmosphere or quality that creates nervous discomfort or mild fear
examples: The spooky old house creaked in the wind
Strange spooky noises came from the attic at night
The spooky coincidence made everyone feel uneasy
That spooky forest path looked dangerous after dark

definitions: happening at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated
appearing or happening infrequently and without any regular pattern or schedule
examples: Sporadic gunfire could be heard throughout the night
The region experienced sporadic rainfall during the drought
Her sporadic attendance made it hard to track progress
They maintained sporadic contact over the years

definitions: connected with or interested in sports and athletic activities
showing fairness, generosity, and good sportsmanship in competition or dealings
examples: The sporting goods store sold equipment for every sport
Major sporting events attract thousands of spectators
It was sporting of him to give his opponent another chance
She made a sporting gesture by congratulating her rival

definitions: inclined to play or frolic in a lively, lighthearted manner
of or relating to sports and athletic activities in general
examples: The sportive puppies chased each other around the yard
Children were in a sportive mood during recess
His sportive interests included tennis and swimming
The sportive atmosphere at the gym was energizing

definitions: fond of or good at sports and physical activities
having a casual, athletic style in appearance or design
examples: The sporty teenager played three different varsity sports
She maintained a sporty lifestyle with daily exercise
His sporty car could accelerate incredibly fast
The sporty jacket was perfect for outdoor activities

definitions: absolutely clean and free from any dirt, marks, or stains
completely free from moral blemish or reproach; having perfect reputation
examples: The spotless kitchen passed the health inspection easily
She kept her white uniform spotless throughout the shift
His spotless reputation made him the ideal candidate
The company maintained a spotless safety record

definitions: having spots or patches of color or texture different from the surroundings
seen, noticed, or identified, especially something difficult to detect
examples: The spotted leopard blended into the dappled shade
She wore a spotted dress to the garden party
The celebrity was spotted leaving the restaurant late
Eagles were spotted nesting in the nearby cliffs

definitions: covered with spots or patches of different color or texture
occurring unevenly or inconsistently; not uniform in quality or performance
examples: The spotty rash on his arm concerned the doctor
Her spotty complexion improved with proper skincare
Their spotty internet connection frustrated remote workers
The team's spotty performance disappointed their coach

definitions: of or relating to marriage or to a married couple's relationship
examples: Spousal support payments were arranged during the divorce
The company extended spousal benefits to all employees
Spousal abuse cases require immediate legal intervention
They attended spousal counseling to improve their marriage

definitions: spreading out over a large area in an untidy or irregular way
extending outward haphazardly or without apparent design or plan
examples: The sprawling city extended far into the countryside
A sprawling mansion dominated the hilltop estate
His sprawling handwriting was difficult to read
The sprawling narrative confused many readers

definitions: stretched out or extended over a surface or area
distributed or occurring throughout a large area or number of people
examples: The spread wings of the eagle measured six feet
Maps were spread across the conference table
The spread infection affected multiple communities
News of the scandal spread quickly through social media

definitions: full of energy and enthusiasm, especially despite advanced age; vivacious and spirited
examples: The sprightly grandmother danced at every family wedding
Her sprightly manner brightened everyone's day
The sprightly tune had everyone tapping their feet
Despite his age, he maintained a sprightly pace

definitions: having produced new growth, shoots, or buds from seeds or roots
examples: The sprouted potatoes were no longer safe to eat
Sprouted grains provide additional nutritional benefits
Recently sprouted seedlings filled the greenhouse trays
His newly sprouted beard changed his appearance completely

definitions: neat, clean, and smart in appearance; well-groomed and tidy
examples: He looked spruce in his freshly pressed uniform
The spruce appearance of the shop attracted customers
She kept her garden spruce throughout the season
The spruce cabin welcomed weary travelers

definitions: moving quickly and easily despite age; nimble and energetic
examples: The spry elderly man climbed stairs without difficulty
She remained spry well into her nineties
His spry movements surprised everyone at his age
The spry cat leaped effortlessly onto the fence

definitions: showing spirit, courage, and determination; full of spirited energy
examples: The spunky teenager stood up to the school bullies
Her spunky attitude impressed the talent scouts
The spunky little dog defended its much larger owner
A spunky performance earned her the leading role

definitions: not being what it purports to be; false or fake but appearing genuine
based on false reasoning or information; lacking validity or authenticity
examples: The spurious antique was actually made last year
Spurious claims about the product misled consumers
His spurious argument failed to convince the jury
The spurious correlation didn't indicate actual causation

definitions: rejected with disdain or contempt; refused or dismissed scornfully
examples: The spurned lover wrote desperate letters for months
His spurned advances made the workplace uncomfortable
The spurned proposal left the team feeling defeated
Spurned applicants received no explanation for rejection

definitions: extremely dirty and unpleasant, especially as a result of poverty or neglect
showing or involving a contemptible lack of moral standards
examples: The squalid apartment hadn't been cleaned in months
Refugees lived in squalid conditions at the camp
The squalid details of the scandal shocked everyone
His squalid behavior at the party disgusted guests

definitions: wasted in a reckless or foolish manner; spent or used carelessly
examples: His squandered inheritance left him penniless
The squandered opportunity haunted her for years
Squandered resources led to the project's failure
Their squandered talent disappointed coaches and fans

definitions: having four equal straight sides and four right angles
having or forming a right angle; positioned at ninety degrees
fair and honest in dealings; straightforward and conventional
examples: The square table seated four people comfortably
She drew a perfect square on the paper
Make sure the corners are square before nailing
His square shoulders gave him an imposing presence
Let's be square with each other about this deal
His square dealing earned everyone's trust

definitions: made into or having the shape of a square
raised to the second power; multiplied by itself
examples: The squared corners of the frame looked modern
Carefully squared edges gave the project professional finish
Five squared equals twenty-five
The squared term dominated the equation

definitions: pressed or crushed into a flat or compressed shape
examples: The squashed bug left a stain on the windshield
Her squashed sandwich was still edible
The squashed boxes barely fit in the recycling bin
A squashed hat emerged from his suitcase

definitions: short and thick; having a low, broad, sturdy appearance
in a position with knees bent and body low to ground
examples: The squat building looked solid and unmovable
A squat mushroom grew beside the fallen log
The squat position strengthened her leg muscles
They found him in a squat position behind the desk

definitions: making or liable to make a high-pitched sound or cry
examples: The squeaky door needed oil on its hinges
Her squeaky voice annoyed the other students
The squeaky floorboards revealed his midnight snacking
A squeaky toy kept the puppy entertained

definitions: characterized by partially closed eyes or looking with eyes partly shut
examples: His squint expression showed his confusion
The squint look she gave suggested suspicion
Squint lines around his eyes deepened when he smiled
The doctor examined the child's squint condition

definitions: causing a sharp, sudden, intense sensation like being stabbed
examples: A stabbing pain shot through her lower back
The stabbing headache made concentration impossible
His stabbing remarks hurt more than physical blows
Stabbing guilt consumed her after the lie

definitions: brought to or maintained in a stable, balanced, or unchanging state
examples: The stabilised economy attracted foreign investors
Her stabilised condition allowed visitors
The stabilised platform provided steady camera shots
Stabilised prices brought relief to consumers

definitions: having the effect of making something stable or preventing change
examples: The stabilising influence of experienced staff helped
Stabilising forces prevented the structure from collapsing
A stabilising medication controlled her mood swings
The stabilising effect of the new policy was immediate

definitions: brought to or maintained in a stable, balanced, or steady state
examples: The stabilized patient was moved from intensive care
Stabilized markets encouraged new investments
The stabilized aircraft continued its flight safely
Her stabilized mood improved family relationships

definitions: having the effect of making something stable or steady; preventing unwanted change
examples: The stabilizing medication prevented dangerous mood swings
Stabilizing forces kept the ship upright
A stabilizing influence on the team came from veterans
The stabilizing bar improved vehicle handling

definitions: firmly fixed or established; not likely to move, change, or fail
emotionally balanced and not easily upset or disturbed
not likely to change or fluctuate; maintaining constant state
examples: The stable structure survived the earthquake
She needed stable ground to set up the telescope
His stable personality made him a reliable friend
The stable patient no longer needed constant monitoring
Stable prices helped consumers plan their budgets
The stable climate supported diverse agriculture

definitions: performed with each note sharply detached or separated from others
examples: The staccato notes created a playful rhythm
Her staccato speech pattern revealed her nervousness
Staccato bursts of gunfire echoed through streets
The pianist's staccato technique was perfectly precise

definitions: arranged in a pile or layers one on top of another
having an attractive, curvaceous body shape, especially referring to bust
examples: The stacked boxes reached the warehouse ceiling
Stacked dishes dried beside the kitchen sink
The stacked actress turned heads at the premiere
His stacked physique came from years of training

definitions: carefully arranged for a particular purpose or effect, often deceptively
organized or arranged to occur in distinct phases or steps
examples: The staged photograph fooled news outlets worldwide
Their staged argument was meant to distract attention
The staged withdrawal of troops took several months
A staged approach to reform proved most effective

definitions: so surprisingly impressive as to cause amazement or disbelief
examples: The staggering cost of healthcare shocked many families
A staggering number of people attended the protest
Her staggering beauty left him speechless
The staggering complexity of the problem discouraged solutions

definitions: having no current or flow; not moving or circulating
showing no activity, growth, or development; inactive or sluggish
examples: Stagnant water in the pond bred mosquitoes
The stagnant air made breathing difficult
The stagnant economy worried government officials
Her stagnant career needed a dramatic change

definitions: serious, boring, and unadventurous; respectable but dull and conventional
examples: The staid banker never took unnecessary risks
Their staid lifestyle lacked excitement or spontaneity
The staid ceremony followed traditional protocols precisely
His staid demeanor hid a wild imagination

definitions: marked or discolored by something that soaks in or adheres
having one's reputation or character damaged or tarnished
examples: The stained carpet needed professional cleaning
His stained shirt revealed his messy eating habits
Her stained reputation never fully recovered
The stained legacy of colonialism persists today

definitions: no longer fresh and pleasant to eat; dry and unappetizing
lacking in freshness, originality, or interest through overuse
examples: The stale bread was too hard to eat
Stale air filled the abandoned building
His stale jokes no longer made anyone laugh
The stale plot failed to engage readers

definitions: having or growing on a stalk or stem-like support structure
examples: The stalked mushrooms grew in clusters
Stalked barnacles attached to the ship's hull
Her stalked eyes were a unique genetic trait
The stalked plant swayed gently in breeze

definitions: loyal, reliable, and hard-working in support or service
strongly built and sturdy; showing physical strength and determination
examples: His stalwart support never wavered during hard times
The stalwart defender of civil rights continued fighting
The stalwart oak tree weathered countless storms
Stalwart athletes competed despite harsh conditions

definitions: used or accepted as normal or average; typical and widely used
conforming to established or accepted level of quality or attainment
examples: The standard procedure took about an hour
Standard equipment comes with every new car
This meets standard requirements for the position
Standard testing protocols ensure consistent results

definitions: brought into conformity with a standard; made consistent across different contexts
examples: Standardised tests measured student progress nationally
The standardised format simplified data analysis
Standardised procedures reduced errors significantly
Their standardised approach ensured quality control

definitions: brought into conformity with established standards; made uniform across applications
examples: Standardized testing created controversy among educators
The standardized forms streamlined the application process
Standardized measurements ensured accurate comparisons
A standardized curriculum was adopted district-wide
